<p>
Counting is an important mathematical tool to analyze many problems that arise in computer science. Counting is useful, for example,  to understand the amount of a particular resource used in a computer system or computation. Counting is also used to determine the number of valid passwords for a security system or addresses in a network to ensure that there are enough unique choices to meet the demand. Counting is also at the heart of discrete probability, which is central to many areas of science. 
</p>

<h3>The product rule</h3>

<p>
The two most basic rules of counting are the sum rule and the product rule.
These two rules applied in different combinations can be used to handle many counting problems.
<span data-definition="true">The <span class="term" obeycase="true" data-term="true">product rule</span> provides a way to count sequences. </span>
While sequences may not seem like a
particularly common type of object to count, many sets can be expressed
as sets of sequences. </p>

        <div>
<h3>The sum rule</h3>

<p>
In the breakfast example, the product rule is applied because 
the customer selects a drink and a main course and a side.
In contrast, <span data-definition="true">the <span class="term" obeycase="true" data-term="true">sum rule</span> is applied when multiple choices are available, but only one selection is made.</span>
For example, suppose a customer just orders a drink. The customer selects a hot drink
or a cold drink.         <div>
<p>
In the next example, a customer purchasing a laptop can select three different sizes of screens
and has a choice between two different processor speeds. For storage, the customer can select a hard disk drive or a solid state drive. The hard disk drive option comes in two sizes, and the solid state option has three different sizes. The manufacturer needs to know how many different configurations are possible. The number of choices is worked out in the animation below:
</p>

        <span class="assistive-text whitespace-pre-wrap" id="text-description-ember151">Static figure: Laptop customization choices:
Screen size = ( 14 in, 15 in, 17 in)
Processor speed = (2.0 GHz, 2.7 GHz)
Storage = Solid State Drive (SSD) or Hard Disk Drive (HDD)
SSD choices: ( 128 G, 256 G, 512 G)
HDD choices: ( 256 G, 512 G )
Laptop Selection:
( Screen size, Processor speed, Storage)
3 choices, 2 choices, SSD 3 choices or HDD 2 choices
Number of choices: 3 times 2 times (3 plus 2) = 30
Step 1:  Customizing a laptop includes the choice of screen size, processor speed, and storage. There are 3 screen sizes and 2 possible processor speeds.
Laptop customization choices are shown along with the setup for laptop selection: (Screen size, Processor speed, Storage)
Step 2:  The number of different laptops is 3 times 2 times (number of choices for storage). Storage can be SSD (3 different sizes) or HDD (2 different sizes).
The number of choices for each feature appears: screen size - 3 choices, processor speed - 2 choices, storage - 3 choices for SSD and 2 choices for HDD
Step 3:  The number of choices for SSD and HDD are combined by the sum rule. The total number of choices for the laptop is 3 times 2 times (3 + 2).
The expression and value for the total number of choices appears: Number of choices: 3 times 2 times (3 plus 2) = 30</span>

A person witnesses a crime and remembers some information about the license plate of the getaway car. The authorities need to figure out how many license plates need to be checked in each case. For each constraint given below, indicate the number of license plates that satisfy that constraint.
</p>
<p>Note: The answer can contain multiplications and power. Calculating the number is not necessary.</p>
</div><!----><!---->

</div><!----><!---->

a lunch special. How many different ways are there to select lunches for the week?

considered different.</p>
<p>One possible selection:</p>
<ul>
<li>Mon: Kung pao chicken</li>
<li> Tues: Beef with broccoli</li>
<li> Wed: Kung pao chicken</li>
<li> Thurs: Moo shu pork</li>
<li> Fri: Beef with broccoli</li>
</ul>

<p>A different selection:</p>

<ul>
<li>Mon: Beef with broccoli</li>
<li> Tues: Kung pao chicken</li>
<li> Wed: Kung pao chicken</li>
<li> Thurs: Moo shu pork</li>
<li> Fri: Beef with broccoli</li>
</ul>
